title.value: Identifiability of Discretized Latent Coordinate Systems via Density Landmarks Detection
title.justification: This is the title provided at the beginning of the paper.
title.quote: Identifiability of Discretized Latent Coordinate Systems via Density Landmarks Detection

extractions.description: This paper introduces a novel form of identifiability, termed quantized coordinate identifiability. The authors prove that it's possible to recover discretized latent coordinates under a highly generic nonlinear smooth mapping, assuming that latent density has axis-aligned discontinuity landmarks. This relaxes the usual assumptions on the independence of factors or the form of the mapping, contributing to disentanglement and representation learning theories.

type.justification: The paper focuses on proving a new form of identifiability theoretically without performing empirical studies or experiments.
type.quote: We introduce this novel form of identifiability, termed quantized coordinate identifiability, and provide a comprehensive proof of the recovery of discretized coordinates.

name.justification: The paper addresses the theoretical framework for unsupervised identifiability of latent factors, which is a critical concept in unsupervised learning.
name.quote: We revisit and tackle the problem of fully unsupervised identifiability of latent factors in the same challenging setting.

name.justification: The paper focuses on developing and proving new forms of identifiability, which is a subfield of broader unsupervised learning theory.
name.quote: Identifiability provides the theoretical grounding for disentanglement to be well-founded.

name.justification: The ultimate goal of the proposed theory is to improve our understanding and performance in representation learning, specifically through disentanglement of latent factors.
name.quote: The goal of representation learning is, thus, to detect and model relevant structure in the distribution of observed data, and expose it into useful compact representations, to facilitate good generalization and sample-efficient learning of subsequent tasks.

name.justification: The paper mentions using the NASA Exoplanet Archive dataset to show evidence of grid structure in real-world data.
name.quote: For example, we find evidence of grid structure in the real-world dataset of exoplanets, shown in Figure 2. The NASA Exoplanet Archive (Akeson et al., 2013) contains physical measurements of exoplanets.

referenced_paper_title.value: The NASA exoplanet archive: Data and tools for exoplanet research
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the reference paper for the NASA Exoplanet Archive, as mentioned in the citation.

name.justification: The paper also mentions creating and using synthetic data for proof-of-concept experimentation.
name.quote: We generate a grid of points by establishing a prior for each cell, such that the sum of the priors of all the cells equals 1.

referenced_paper_title.justification: This dataset has been generated by the authors themselves for experimental purposes and does not have a reference paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We generate a grid of points by establishing a prior for each cell, such that the sum of the priors of all the cells equals 1.
